title-group.article-title: Stock Return Predictability and the Dispersion in Earnings Forecasts*

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2005 by The University of Chicago. All rights reserved.

abstract.p: Using monthly data for earnings forecasts by market analysts, this paper shows that the dispersion in forecasts has particularly strong predictive power for future aggregate stock returns at intermediate horizons. The results are robust (1) regardless of whether Newey-West or Hodrick correctedt-statistics are used, (2) when other forecasting or macroeconomic variables are included, (3) when different scaling variables are used for the dispersion measure, and (4) after correcting for finite sample biases. Furthermore, additional results suggest that the dispersion in analysts' forecasts can be interpreted as a measure of the differences in investors' expectations rather than the risk.

fn.p: A previous version of this paper appeared under the title “Stock Returns and the Dispersion in Earnings Forecasts” and was part of my Ph. D. dissertation at the University of Michigan—Ann Arbor. I am grateful to Robert Barsky, E. Han Kim, and Matthew Shapiro for their guidance, comments, and discussions. I also thank an anonymous referee, Bokhyeon Baik, Lutz Kilian, Jin Lee, Dmitriy Stolyarov, and participants of seminars at National University of Singapore, University of Michigan, and University of New Hampshire for valuable comments. Special thanks go to I/B/E/S Inc. for providing the data used in this paper and to Shirley Fong and Manoj Raj for research assistance. I am responsible for any errors herein. Contact the author at ecscp@nus.edu.sg.

body.p: The predictability of stock returns has been well documented in an extensive literature. For example, Campbell and Shiller (1988a,1988b), Fama and French (1988), Campbell (1991), and Lamont (1998) report that financial variables, such as the relative short‐term Treasury bill rate, and the ratios of price to dividends, price to earnings, or dividends to earnings, have predictive power for future movements of stock returns.

Economic interpretations on this predictability also abound. The predictability may come from irrational expectations (Barsky and DeLong1993; Cecchetti, Lam, and Mark2000), a time‐varying risk premium (Campbell and Cochrane1999), survivorship bias (Goetzmann and Jorion1995), or it may reflect the statistical illusions of the long‐horizon regressions in the predictability literature (Ang and Bekaert2001).

Although economists have not yet reached a consensus on the source and existence of this predictability, this paper adds to the body evidence supporting the predictability of stock returns by showing that the dispersion in earnings forecasts by analysts also has a predictive power for future stock returns. This finding also points to alternative models to explain the movements of stock prices, because the dispersion in analysts’ forecasts appears more related to a mispricing hypothesis than a time‐varying risk premium or distorted expectations.

According to Miller (1977), only the valuation by more optimistic investors will be reflected in the stock prices in the presence of both heterogeneous expectations among investors and binding short‐sale constraints.1As a result, high (low) dispersion in expectations can predict low (high) stock returns in the future. Diether, Malloy, and Scherbina (2002) and Chen, Hong, and Stein (2002) tested this idea and reported that the dispersion in expectations indeed predicts cross‐sectional differences in individual stock returns. Although this story can be justifiable for individual stocks, it seems difficult to apply to the aggregate stock market. It is hard to accept heterogeneous expectations in the aggregate market where information is transparent and rational investors update their expectations. Binding short‐sale constraints are also difficult to justify for stocks in the Standard and Poor's 500 (S&P 500) index, because these stocks are easy to borrow.

However, some pieces of indirect evidence may suggest that the situation in the aggregate market is not much different from that of individual stocks with idiosyncratic valuations. Whether heterogeneous expectations stem from overconfidence or different subjective probability assessments, heterogeneous expectations are found in most survey data sets for aggregate variables. Using survey data from participants in the yen‐dollar exchange rate market, Ito (1990) reports that market participants' expectations are irrational and heterogeneous. Furthermore, with almost identical data, Elliott and Ito (1999) show that a simple trading strategy based on individual participants' expectations can create average positive profits. This evidence shows that, unlike the economists' conjecture that only investors with the rational expectation would survive in the aggregate market, many heterogeneous expectations coexist in aggregate financial markets, even though some expectations appear irrational.

In addition, although short sales of stocks in the S&P 500 index generally require lower cost than other stocks, in practice, short sales in the aggregate market are not made widely. D'Avolio (2002) reports that, although the aggregate market is easy to borrow from, only 7% of stocks which could go short were borrowed between April 2000 and September 2001. Also, most institutional traders do not go short (Almazan et al.2004), and the average outstanding value of short sale obligation of the S&P 500 has been, from 1974 to 1983, about 0.2% of the total value (Morris1996). Although it is beyond the scope of this paper to ascertain why investors are reluctant to go short, these statistics imply that short sales are rare in practice and binding short‐sale constraints would not be a bad simplification of the aggregate market.

Hence, this paper tests whether the aggregate stock market also becomes overpriced when differences in expectations are high, through investigation of the predictive power of the dispersion in forecasts for earnings in the S&P 500 index. For the analysis, I use two alternative procedures in constructing the standard errors to correct for heteroscedasticity and serial correlation in the errors of the long‐horizon regressions. One is Newey‐West (1987) standard errors, which are popular in the literature; the other is Hodrick (1992) standard errors, which are preferred in Hodrick (1992) and Ang and Bekaert (2001). Althought‐statistics based on Hodrick standard errors are generally more conservative than Newey‐West standard errors,t‐tests based on both standard errors provide strong evidence that the dispersion in expectations among market analysts has predictive power for future stock returns. These results suggest the existence of mispricing at the aggregate level similarly to those of Baker and Stein (2004), who provide the evidence of mispricing at the aggregate level from the predictive power of the liquidity measure.

To show the predictive power of the dispersion in forecasts, the paper proceeds as follows. Section I discusses how to measure the dispersion and reports summary statistics for the dispersion in earnings forecasts for the S&P 500 index. Section II addresses two main issues: whether the dispersion in expectations has any predictive power for future stock returns and whether it contains information aside from that contained in other variables used to forecast future stock returns. The results in this section show that the dispersion seems to have particularly strong predictive power for future stock returns at intermediate horizons (from 17 to 33 months when Hodrick standard errors are used fort‐statistics). Section III demonstrates that the predictive power of the dispersion at intermediate horizons survives robustness checks from various perspectives. Section IV examines the relation of the dispersion with the market volatility and the trading volume. Finally, concluding remarks are offered in Section V.

fn.p: Miller (1977) and Harrison and Kreps (1978) examine the consequence of heterogeneous expectations and short‐sale constraints. For more recent theoretical research, see Morris (1996) and Scheinkman and Xiong (2003).

sec.label: I.
sec.title: Data and Construction of Variables
sec.p: This section discusses how to measure the dispersion in 1‐year‐ahead earnings forecasts and shows summary statistics for the dispersion. The dispersion in this paper is defined as the ratio of the standard deviation in analysts’ earnings forecasts to actual earnings. The reason for normalizing the standard deviation by the realized earnings is to exclude the effect that the standard deviation of forecasts increases with actual earnings. Thus, by definition, the dispersion is independent of the inflation rate.

The standard deviation in the earnings forecasts for the S&P 500 index is taken from the Institutional Brokers Estimate System (I/B/E/S) data set. I/B/E/S is a Wall Street research firm that collects forecasts for the S&P 500 index and individual company earnings for current and subsequent fiscal years from stock market analysts every month. I/B/E/S specifically asks for forecasts of operating earnings per share, which excludes nonrecurring or unusual expenses or income, such as restructuring costs or unusual capital gains or losses.

This measure of the dispersion is different from that in Diether et al. (2002) in two respects. First, an adjustment is taken to hold the forecast horizon constant. Although it is not perfect, this adjustment is important because the dispersion is expected to depend on the forecast horizon. Second, the standard deviation is normalized by actual earnings rather than the mean of earnings forecasts to eliminate possible forecastability from earnings forecasts in the denominator. An investigation about whether the change in the scaling variable, from the mean of earnings forecasts to the actual earnings, affects the result is provided in Section III.

Except for the standard deviations in earnings forecasts data, all the data used for the analysis of the aggregate market (e.g., the S&P 500 monthly price index, S&P 500 monthly dividend yield, S&P 500 monthly price‐earnings ratio, monthly consumer price index, industrial production, and Treasury bill rates) are from the DRI database. The appendix explains how to construct monthly real stock returns for the aggregate S&P 500 and how to calculate financial indicators such as the ratios of price to dividends, price to earnings, or dividends to earnings between January 1982 and July 2001.

fn.p: Since analysts' forecasts for the aggregate S&P 500 earnings per share have not been adjusted for stock splits, these forecasts are immune to the bias problem documented by Diether et al. (2002).

The data for earnings for the S&P 500 index are constructed from the monthly S&P 500 index and its price‐earnings ratio in the DRI database. See the appendix for a detailed explanation of the construction of this variable.
I am grateful to an anonymous referee for suggesting this point.

sec.label: II.
sec.title: Long‐Horizon Regression with Dispersion
sec.p:
This section addresses the issue of whether the dispersion in expectations has any predictive power for future stock returns, and the issue of whether it contains information aside from the information contained in other variables used in forecasting future stock returns. One easy and popular way to judge the predictive ability of a variable on future stock returns is to check the significance of the coefficient of the variable and theR 2in the long‐horizon regressions. Hence, the following long‐horizon regression is implemented:

The significance of the coefficient is reported using both Newey‐West standard errors and Hodrick standard errors, as Ang and Bekaert (2001) report a discrepancy between the measures. Over the sample period covered in this paper, the dispersion appears to predict future stock returns from a 12‐month horizon to a 39‐month horizon when Newey‐West standard errors are used. If Hodrick standard errors are used, then the dispersion has a predictive power for future stock returns between a 17‐month horizon and a 33‐month horizon. Although there is a discrepancy between the Newey‐West and Hodrickt‐statistics, both measures of thet‐statistics demonstrate that the dispersion has a predictive power at intermediate horizons. During these horizons, the coefficient of the dispersion in the regression is significantly negative, and the dispersion alone appears to explain up to 21% of the movements in future stock returns. The estimated coefficients in the regression imply that the dispersion higher than the average by two standard deviations predicts 16% lower stock return over 30 months.5These results are generally consistent with the results for individual stocks of Chen et al. (2002) and Diether et al. (2002).6

Another issue to address is whether the dispersion in earnings forecasts contains any incremental information about the future movements of stock returns aside from the information contained in other available variables. To investigate this possibility, the following regression is run:
where \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $Z_{t}$ \end{document} is composed of all the popular forecasting variables in the previous section to examine whether the dispersion really provides additional information with regard to future stock returns.

fn.p: Since the standard deviation of the dispersion intable 1is 0.0213, I can have 2 × 3.8696 × 0.0213 = 0.1648.

According to Diether et al. (2002), the results for cross‐sectional differences in returns are strong at short return horizons and become weaker as the return horizon increases. This issue is discussed in the next section.
Possible finite sample bias problems are discussed in the next section.

Thet‐statistics of the dispersion become a little smaller with the inclusion of the forecasting variables in the regression. However, this could be consistent with the mispricing hypothesis, because the log earnings price ratio (or the log dividends price ratio) and the dispersion are expected to be negatively related and pick up a similar phenomenon in future returns under the hypothesis, as discussed in the previous section.
The results are not sensitive to the choice among 3‐month, 6‐month, or 1‐year Treasury bill rates.
The Schwarz criterion is consistent in lag order selection. The lag order, based on the Schwarz criterion, is 1 and the qualitative results are not sensitive to the choice of lag order.

sec.label: III.
sec.title: Robustness Tests
sec.p: To ascertain that the stock return predictability from the dispersion in analysts’ forecasts presented in the previous section is not spurious, I conduct robustness tests from various perspectives in this section.

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Different Forecast Horizon in the Dispersion
sec.p: In the previous section, the dispersion in analysts' forecasts has significant predictive power for future stock returns at intermediate horizons (from 17 months to 33 months when Hodrick standard errors are used fort‐statistics). However, Diether et al. (2002) show that the dispersion in analysts' forecasts for individual stocks has strong predictive power for cross‐sectional differences in returns at short horizons and this power becomes weaker as the return horizon increases. Although it is hard to make a direct comparison between the time‐series predictive power for future stock returns and the predictive power for cross‐sectional differences in returns, it is worthwhile to examine the source of this difference in results.

One possible source of the difference is the difference in forecasting horizons when the dispersions are constructed. Since the dispersion in this paper is constructed from the weighted average of the current‐year earnings forecasts and the following‐year earnings forecasts, the exact forecast horizon is between 10 and 22 months. In contrast, the exact forecast horizon in Diether et al. (2002) is less than 12 months, since they use only the current‐year earnings forecasts. Hence, the forecast horizon in this paper is much longer. To examine whether the difference in results stems from the difference in the forecast horizon, a dispersion measure with a shorter forecast horizon is constructed and used in long‐horizon regressions.

The dispersion measure with a shorter forecast horizon is similarly constructed from the weighted average of the current‐quarter forecasts and the following‐quarter forecasts to approximate the dispersion of 1‐quarter‐ahead earnings forecasts. I/B/E/S has been reporting current‐quarter and following‐quarter earnings forecasts since April 1984. However, since the number of analysts who reported current‐quarter and following‐quarter forecasts is far less than the number of analysts who reported current‐year and following‐year forecasts, missing values for the current‐quarter and following‐quarter forecasts are often observed. As a result, the dispersion measure with a shorter forecast horizon could be constructed only from April 1987 to September 1999 without discontinuity.

Table 5shows the results of long‐horizon regressions with a shorter forecast‐horizon dispersion measure. Similarly to the results intable 2, the coefficients of the dispersion andR 2increase with the length of horizon. While there is a sharp discrepancy between Hodrick standard errors and Newey‐West standard errors,11the new dispersion has significant predictive power at short horizons (1–3 months) with both measures of standard errors.12This result implies that the difference in forecast horizon in Diether et al. (2002) and this paper is a source of the difference in the predictive power horizon. Furthermore, the remarkable predictive power at short horizons in this subsection avoids complicating statistical issues associated with long‐horizon regressions.13

fn.p: The sharp discrepancy may result from the smaller sample size for the dispersion with a shorter forecast horizon.
The strong predictive power of the dispersion in 1‐quarter‐ahead forecasts survives at short horizons, even when other forecasting or macroeconomic variables are included in long‐horizon regressions.
I am grateful to an anonymous referee for this point.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Different Scaling Variable
sec.p: To construct the dispersion in this paper, actual earnings are used to deal with possible nonstationarity in the standard deviation of earnings forecasts. However, one may think that scaling by actual earnings is a reason for the lack of return predictability at short horizons because earnings also have predictive power for future stock returns at short horizons, as shown by Lamont (1998). For example, even if there is aggregate mispricing in the market, high dispersion, due to a high standard deviation in earnings forecasts and low actual earnings, may not have a clear predictive power at short horizons because the high standard deviation predicts low returns while low earnings forecasts high returns at short horizons. To address this possibility, another dispersion measure, scaled by the absolute value of the mean forecast, is used in long‐horizon regressions.

The results are shown intable 6. Generally, the dispersion measure, scaled by the absolute value of the mean forecast, has a slightly weaker predictive power than the dispersion measure scaled by actual earnings, which is more pronounced at short horizons unlike the preceding conjecture. However, with both Hodrick and Newey‐West standard errors, the dispersion measure scaled by the absolute value of the mean forecast also has strong predictive power for stock returns at intermediate horizons (28‐to 30‐month horizons). Therefore, the results suggest that the lack of return predictability at short horizons is not a consequence of the dispersion being scaled by actual earnings.14

sec.label: C.
sec.title: Finite Sample Bias and Monte Carlo Simulation
sec.p: Although the predictability of the dispersion can be observed by long‐horizon regressions, there are two major pitfalls in applying the asymptotic theory tot‐statistics in long‐horizon regressions (Campbell, Lo, and MacKinlay1997, chap. 7). The first problem arises from the persistence of regressors in long‐horizon regressions. The second problem arises because observations in the dependent variable of the long‐horizon regression overlap. This problem could be serious, especially when the horizonKis large relative to the sample size. The long‐horizon regressions in this paper may have these problems. As a result, some finite sample biases appear to be unavoidable.

As shown intable 7, the 5% critical value for thet‐statistics with the Newey‐West standard errors becomes greater in magnitude as the horizon increases, indicating that the finite sample bias becomes more serious with the length of horizon. However, the 5% critical value for thet‐statistics with the Hodrick standard errors does not show clear tendency in magnitude, which implies that the Hodrick standard errors would perform better in a finite sample. Nevertheless, the distortion does not seem to be great enough to reject the previous results in either case, since the actualt‐statistics for the dispersion are greater in magnitude than the 5% critical values from the simulated empirical distribution at intermediate horizons. This implies that the actualt‐statistics obtained in the long‐horizon regressions are very rare under the null hypothesis. For example, when the Newey‐West correctedt‐statistics are used, thep‐value is even lower than 1% at the 30‐month horizon. With both measures of standard errors, therefore, the null hypothesis that the dispersion has no predictive power for future stock returns at intermediate horizons can be rejected at a conventional significance level. sec.label: IV.
sec.title: Interpreting the Predictability from the Dispersion
sec.p: If the dispersion in analysts’ forecasts has considerable power to predict future stock returns, then why does the dispersion have this predictive power? I address this question by investigating the relations of the dispersion with market volatility and trading volume to see whether the dispersion can be interpreted as the risk or differences in investors’ expectations.

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Dispersion and Market Volatility
sec.p: Although there is no direct connection between stock market volatility and the dispersion in forecasts, these two concepts might be indirectly connected.16There could be more disagreement among analysts when an asset becomes more risky because market volatility normally reflects the risk and uncertainty of an asset at each moment. Thus, it would be reasonable to suppose that the market volatility of stock returns would increase as the dispersion in forecasts increases. In other words, volatility and dispersion are expected to covary.

Although there are many ways to estimate volatility in the stock market, the volatility in this paper is estimated under autoregressive conditional heteroscedasticity (ARCH) (1), generalized ARCH (GARCH) (1, 1) and GARCH in mean with autoregression (AR) (1) specifications, because the GARCH‐type models are widely used in financial economics since being introduced by Engel (1982). As one can obtain very similar volatility estimates under all specifications, the results intable 8and the upper panel offigure 2are shown only for the GARCH (1, 1) specification. Table 8

fn.p: While the dispersion shows differences in prior beliefs or probability density functions across investors, the market volatility normally means the variance from the homogeneous probability density function or the uncertainty in market returns.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Dispersion and Trading Volume
sec.p: Many theoretical studies, such as Harris and Raviv (1993) and Hong and Stein (2003), have shown that trading volume will be high when disagreement among investors is high. Furthermore, Diether et al. (2002) report that trading volume and dispersion in analysts’ forecasts are related for individual stocks, and Lee and Swaminathan (2000) find that trading volume helps predict individual stock returns. Hence, this subsection investigates the relation between trading volume and the dispersion in analysts’ forecasts in the aggregate market. This investigation also makes it possible to check the validity of the implicit assumption that the dispersion in analysts’ forecasts is closely related with the dispersion in investors’ forecasts.

The trading volume of the S&P 500 index is measured as a value‐weighted average of the trading volume of the constituent firms in the index while the trading volume of individual firms is defined as the ratio of the number of shares traded each month to the number of shares outstanding at the end of each month. The weight is given by the market value of constituent firms at the end of each month. The list of constituent firms in the index is reconstructed from the list of firms in the index as of March 1982 and the Standard and Poor's record of additions and deletions to and from the index.17There were 939 firms included in the index between March 1982 and July 2001. Among them, 14 firms have no matched data for the trading volume at the Center for Research in Securities Prices (CRSP). As a result, the aggregate trading volume for the S&P 500 index is constructed with the exclusion of these 14 firms.

As shown in the lower panel offigure 2, the level of the trading volume series exhibits a clear upward trend. There could be various reasons for this trend, but one possible explanation would be that the recent development in information technology has a significant impact on trading volume. Since technological development has reduced the trading costs, the trading volume has increased even if the investors’ disagreement process has not changed. As a result, the trading volume series has been detrended to eliminate effects from the change in trading costs and assure stationarity in the regression. Methods commonly used in detrending trading volume are lacking in theoretical fundamentals. Nevertheless, the method employed in Gallant, Rossi, and Tauchen (1992) is used, where the detrending is done by fitting a second‐order polynomial time trend and monthly dummy variables to the series.18The augmented Dickey‐Fuller test statistic (−2.2391)19and the first‐order autocorrelation (0.7139) of the detrended trading volume suggest that the detrended series can be taken as stationary.

However, a subperiod analysis provides further insight into the relation. The second panel oftable 9shows that there was a tight relation between the detrended trading volume and dispersion at the aggregate level during the 1980s. The trading volume can explain over 17% of the variation in the dispersion. Trading volume (dispersion) Granger‐causes the dispersion (trading volume) at a conventional significance level.20However, this strong relation was broken in the later time period. The third panel oftable 9shows that the detrended trading volume no longer has a significant coefficient in the regression of the dispersion on trading volume. The correlation dropped drastically. Neither detrended trading volume nor dispersion Granger‐causes the other variable.

A subperiod analysis shows that the dispersion has no significant predictive power for future stock returns at intermediate horizons with Hodrick standard errors during the first subperiod (March 1982–December 1990), when the detrended trading volume is included in the long‐horizon regression. As suggested intable 9, this implies that both the dispersion and detrended trading volume have common information that could help predict future stock returns at intermediate horizons. High point estimates of the regression coefficient for the trading volume are consistent with the results in Baker and Stein (2004) during the first subperiod.

However, the predictive power of the dispersion is hardly affected by the inclusion of the detrended trading volume in the regression during the second subperiod (January 1991–July 2001). Like the results intable 2, the dispersion has significant predictive power by both measures of standard errors between 14‐month and 30‐month horizons. Furthermore, the detrended trading volume also has its own (marginally) significant predictive power around 6‐month horizons. This independent predictive power of trading volume at shorter horizons, together with the results from the shorter forecast horizon dispersion intable 5, suggests that the breakdown of the tight relation between two measures during the 1990s may have resulted from the difference in the opinion horizon reflected in the trading volume and the dispersion of 1‐year‐ahead earnings forecasts. A sizeable reduction in the trading cost could enable investors to make decisions more frequently, so that the trading volume contains shorter‐horizon opinion divergence during the 1990s. Since this change may not be well captured by an ordinary detrending method like the one employed in this paper, the difference in forecast horizon could be a possible reason for the breakdown in the relation between the detrended trading volume and dispersion during the 1990s.

In summary, it would be more natural to interpret the dispersion in analysts’ forecasts as the difference in investors’ expectations that can affect trading volume rather than the risk at least during the 1980s.

fn.p: The list is available upon request.
Monthly dummy variables are put in the regression to remove any possible seasonality in the trading volume such as the January effect. See Gallant et al. (1992).
The augmented Dickey‐Fuller test is conducted with no drift, since the trading volume has been detrended.
A similar strong relation also holds for the trading volume in level and the dispersion during the 1980s.

sec.label: V.
sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This paper has shown that the dispersion in analysts’ earnings forecasts has its own predictive power for future stock returns. Two alternative measures of standard errors (Newey‐West1987and Hodrick1992) unanimously present significant coefficients for the dispersion at intermediate horizons. Furthermore, the dispersion measure dominates other forecasting or macroeconomic variables in terms of its predictive power. The difference in the timing of the predictive power between Diether et al. (2002) and this paper appears to result from the difference in the forecast horizon in the dispersion measure. The predictive power of the dispersion at intermediate horizons has survived even when the scaling variable is replaced. The Monte Carlo simulation additionally shows that finite sample biases in long‐horizon regressions using the dispersion do not seem so serious.

Also, while most of the movements in dispersion cannot be explained by the market volatility, the dispersion has a strong relation with trading volume, another measure of the differences in investors’ expectation, at least during the 1980s. Although it is hard to accept heterogeneous expectations and binding short‐sale constraints in the aggregate market, one can easily find heterogeneous expectations in the survey data, and short sales are rarely made, even in the aggregate market. All the evidence in this paper may suggest that the dispersion has a predictive power because stock prices reflect optimistic investors’ valuations.

In this study, the result that the dispersion has a forecasting ability for future aggregate stock returns would seem to warrant a reconsideration of the recent debate on stock return predictability. In addition, the results suggest that the interaction between investors with heterogeneous expectations and its effect on stock price movements, and the reason for investors’ reluctance to borrow stocks would be interesting topics for future research.

app.label: Appendix
app.p: Except for the standard deviations in earnings forecasts data, all the data used for the analysis of the aggregate market (e.g., the S&P 500 monthly price index, S&P 500 monthly dividend yield, S&P 500 monthly price‐earnings ratio, monthly consumer price index, industrial production, and Treasury bill rates) are from the DRI database. The DRI codes for each data series are as follows. The DRI code for the S&P 500 monthly price index is FSPCOM, the code for the S&P 500 monthly dividend yield is FSDXP, the code for the S&P 500 monthly price‐earnings ratio is FSPXE, the code for the monthly consumer price index is PUNEW, the code for industrial production is IP, and the codes for Treasury bill rates are FYGM3, FYGM6, and FYGMYR.
